column421: ECOPs spend a ton of time and energy on always looking for the next position. Moving, etc, takes a toll on both personal and professional advancement. The Decade, with its focus on inclusion, should consider the needs of ECOPs - stability, funding, and retention. Some countries (mine - the US) have extremely limited options for maternity leave, hence there are large #s of women leaving academia because there are very limited options for staying in academia as well as having a family. How will the Decade help support ECOPs facing these issues. The more stability available to ECOPs, the more energy, time, and passion they can devote to addressing the big challenges facing our oceans.

column420: We need more platforms and opportunities for early career professionals to offer their knowledge and have an active seat at the table. We (early career professionals) will eventually inherit today's ocean challenges and have a duty of action to keep the ocean healthy and accessible for future generations. It would be extremely beneficial for us to start taking part in those conversations and decisions NOW, so that we aren't left to deal with decisions that we may not view as ideal for our ocean's future.

column376: As a researcher from a developing country, I would like to contribute to the Decade by improving the existing research capabilities of our institute for ocean science research. These include laboratory capabilities to measure ocean acidification, ocean deoxygenation, eutrophication, and other stressors (intensive and extensive mariculture, tourism, urban development) at the coastal areas. This could also include steps towards the development of national training center on ocean acidification considering the archipelagic setting of our country. I would also like to continue collaboration with international researchers for advanced isotope techniques (e.g. oxygen isotopes of phosphate) to trace the sources of phosphorus pollution in coastal areas (e.g. wasted fish feeds in mariculture areas) and device ways to regenerate phosphorus into usable forms that could help their livelihood (e.g. fertilizer for aquaponics).     I would also like to be involved in strategies to strengthen open ocean and coastal ocean monitoring efforts especially those that are related to hazards such as typhoons, storm surges, harmful algal blooms and fish kills, as well as those related to ocean productivity, fisheries and biodiversity such as understanding the dynamics of unique upwelling areas, eddies, coral reefs and marine protected areas.  I would also like to contribute to the Decade by carrying out research on blue carbon ecosystems such as mangroves and seagrasses. These ecosystems are currently known by stakeholders for the other ecosystem services that they provide but not on the amount of carbon that they lock up in their systems and the sediments and on how they can help mitigate the effects of climate change due to anthropogenic carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. Including the quantification of the sequestered carbon by these carbon sinks will hopefully encourage more management and conservation efforts of these ecosystems.  To complete the holistic approach to ocean science, I would like to contribute to efforts on effective communication of scientific results for science-based policy making. This includes merging the rich knowledge on the ocean by the indigenous communities with the technological advancements in ocean science. This would entail going to communities and carrying out perception surveys about ocean science and translating results into tangible materials. I would like to develop modules on advanced courses on Professional Masters for Tropical Marine Ecosystems Management, the students of which are employees from government implementing agencies. I would like to support efforts that tap citizen scientists and highlight the role of women in communities for ocean science. I would also like to continue the current efforts on developing ecosystem health report cards that raise awareness, instill accountability, and call for action to change the current status.   Zooming out from our archipelagic nation, I would also like to know how other nations are doing by sharing these efforts in a kind of platform that will foster more collaboration with other scientists in my country and in the world that are working with a timeline in mind for the achievements of the goals of the Decade.
column377: Limited funding availability for research; manpower support; technical capacities in utilizing advanced equipment, computer programs and databases; and scope of science communication skills
column420: As much as policymakers’ involvement in the decade are necessary to make sure that proper ocean science-based laws are implemented for a clean, healthy and resilient, predictable, safe, sustainably harvested, and transparent ocean, youth involvement in ECOPs’ and advanced professionals’ activities are likewise very important. This will make them aware of the strategies that are being used to achieve the goals for the ocean decade 2021-2030, and will help them prepare and properly address the concerns for the next decade 2031-2040. They can be involved as young citizen scientists during this decade. Scientific television programs and other learning activities such as field exposure for the youth should also be promoted. Engaging communication at all levels should also be sustained. Tapping technology for ocean literacy such as interactive online courses and informative video clips on the six pillars of ocean science for the Decade.

column420: I think a real challenge in the United States regarding deep sea research has been that while there are resources at the national level for researching the deep sea, they are incredibly limited, and as an individual it is EXTREMELY difficult to obtain access to these resources. For example, I am interested in the effects of climate change on the distribution and abundance of mesopelagic fishes in the California Current. While I am grateful to be able to use my connections as a previous employee in a NOAA lab to access acoustic and oceanographic data incidentally collected by NOAA while targeting other species, I am unable to actually access resources to ever see my study species in situ or plan an experiment to actually examine this question. Barring access to the one dedicated deep sea research vessel in the country (at NOAA) that has the capability of conducting work in the deep sea (which I don't have any real opportunity to do), there is limited amount of work I can do to explore this region (the deep sea) that is the biggest environment on earth!  It thus follows that as we continue to alter the deep sea environment (either directly via mining operations for example, or indirectly via changes to the physical environment via climate change), we do not currently have the scientific capacity to record how these changes are affecting organisms living within these bands. Further, as large swaths of the deep-sea lie beyond national jurisdictions, it is clear that there will be a need for organized, international policy to ensure its health and resiliency into the future.
column421: I think the decade is a wonderful opportunity to showcase some of the scientific needs of the ocean (specifically the Deep Sea in my opinion :) and advocate for the organization of international bodies to set policy into the future!    Thank you for the opportunity to contribute my input, I would be happy to be involved if you are looking for motivated scientists (particularly if it relates to the Deep Sea). Best regards and keep up the good work!

column421: To support the ECOPs, the decade program could promote innovative scientific (research / articles) and technical (engineering) work that fits with the objectives of the program. This promotion can be done via colloquia and training seminars, knowledge exchange and know-how, sharing of information relating to marine sciences, popularization of projects that opt for sustainable development. Thus, scientific, technical, financial assistance at the local, regional and global scales could propel and guarantee the objective quality of the respective participation of the various ECOPs in the UN Decade of Ocean Science for Sustainable Development 2021-2030.

column420: I believe there needs to be an opportunity for youth involvement in these events, but not just youth. There needs to be discussions with those who are directly impacted. Having worked as a fisherman for over a decade, and now in the consulting space, it is highly infrequent that those directly impacted are brought to the forefront to discuss issues. Moreover, there is a large focus on what can be done to help the developing world, but many ocean based industries in the developed world are struggling as well, but are overlooked because in absolute terms they are much better off, but in relative terms their struggle may be more significant.
column421: Get us to the forefront of business and policy leaders discussions. We deserve a spot at the table, yet we normally cannot access it. We don't have the resources (whether it is freedom to visit these events, income, or a combination). Moreover, we need endorsement and support from these leaders. All opportunities to speak to the political, business, and global leaders has been on scholarship, but for every one of these I get, there are hundred or thousands of others who are denied. We need more support. We need more discussions, and we deserve to share our experiences and insights.

column376: The mission of my employer UNEP-WCMC is to connect scientists/data/knowledge with decision-makers. I would like to contribute towards the Decade by building relationships with decision-makers so that they can access the wealth of information and data that we hold here at UNEP-WCMC, so that they can make informed decisions regarding the ocean.

column421: By providing support in career development, since the Decade will take up a substantial part of their early-mid careers. ECOPs will also be the people to 'take the baton' in ocean sustainability when the Decade ends and will be the experts, so by training and supporting them throughout the Decade will ensure the next generation of ocean scientists are of a high standard and have the capability to address the challenges faced by the ocean. The next Decade is a 'now or never' moment for the environment and building capacity in ECOPs will ensure we are in safe hands from 2030 and beyond.  How exactly ECOPs are provided support and their capacity built depends on the specific ways in which they contribute towards ocean sustainability. The needs will differ between scientists, policy makers, etc.

column420: There is a need to stop writting and thinking and start taking action.   Is cristal clear that we have the knowledge to (at least) start changing the world and if we put all the resources and willigness in concrete global and impactful actions ... we can pave the path to a more sustainable, equitative and more just and compassionate world.     This seems imposible but is simple like this.   In terms of fisheries (stop IUU fishing, regulate Sustainable fish stocks, support international fishing management, reduce fishing preassures and advance in selective fishing gears).     This is possible and moreless easy to imeplement. This is very much connected to MSP and Large Marine Ecosystem Areas. Also linked to aquaculture sector which is advancing dayle in terms of sustainability, quality of the product, efficiency and health.     Straight forward actions at global scale (involving goverment, internationa/regional and national funds, touchin on citizen behavior, etc) in these very much simple direction will impact tremendously in both society and the enviroment.     It is a matter of focus and take global decisions. World cannot be anylonger manage by nations (when it comes to sustaianbility). We need  to act at a global scale when it comes to global issues

column376: I think that with studies in the field of impact assessment, mainly in the interrelation between the ways of life of coastal communities and the new fronts of use (wind energy production) for the South Atlantic Ocean (northeast Brazil), I would like to contribute to the production data that highlights the social and environmental complexity existing in oceanic environments. A country's development cannot be considered development if it is unilateral. Equity must be fundamental for sustainable development.

column346: Global climate models predict decreased ocean productivity, but the regional variability of changes in productivity is not well-known and many models disagree on the sign of changes. There is a need for improved scientific understanding of the impact of ocean warming on primary production. This includes more observations of biogeochemical variables and improved models.
column347: As ocean circulation and water masses change due to climate change, ocean users (particularly fisheries) are becoming more reliant on oceanographic measurements to supplement traditional knowledge. However, oceanographic instruments are expensive which makes them inaccessible. There is a need for low-cost and open source oceanographic sensor development.
column348: With increased industrial production, sustenance and artisanal fishing are often threatened. Governance strategies to protect small-scale fishing would benefit enormously from increased scientific understanding of small-scale oceanographic processes and observations of small-scale processes, particularly in the developing world where that information is currently lacking.

column421: Large infrastructure companies, like energy companies, may have a desire to get more engaged in ocean sustainability, but as it is often not the core busines, it becomes difficult to secure the needed budgets to develop and implement solutions where you take adavantage of unique offshore infrastructure oportunities. It is a shame, as the companies themselves, of course, have a better idea of what/what not they potentially could support from a technical point of view. If external (e.g. through UN) budgets where easierly and more obviously available, it could perhaps remove financial barriers for private sector companies to engage more. It would require accesability of UN Ocean Decade resources (staff, knowledge, finance) and could be a public-private sector collaboration that could support a sweep of new and valuable initiatives.

column376: VERY little is known about the habitat and species diversity in Alaska (a massive area with much coastline), primarily because local research focuses on fish and not other guilds. We do not know enough about the seawater chemistry, invertebrate diversity, or macrophyte diversity and associated biology and ecosystem services. I am a new local expert in seagrasses and seaweeds in Alaska and would love to serve as a regional node for all science that is not finfish fisheries.

column376: Promote the desperate need for more social and behavioral ocean science. Natural science is necessary, however the past 5 decades or more have told us that even if we know something is going awry (climate change, ocean plastic, over exploitation of fisheries) does not equate to corrective behavior change from individuals, countries, or as a global community. column346: Coastal systems are heavily tied to upland systems. There is a regulatory gap where land meets the sea, where agencies are only responsible for one or the other (upland or ocean). While I am in the US I’d imagine this happens many places. Because of this separation, agencies trying to protect reefs (e.g. Florida keys) have limited ability to improve water quality that is significantly impacted by larger issues at hand. Around the world we need to stop the separation of land and coastal waters and understand how our use greatly impacts coastal waters and the greater oceans. Seagate spills, erosion issues due to upland Development, leaking septic tanks, fresh water diversion, etc. are all things that impact our coastal systems, but the agencies responsible for protecting the systems have little influence on those stressors. To save the reefs, seagrass meadows, etc, of the Caribbean we need to look beyond these individual impacts and design a more comprehensive look at our ocean systems and supported by scientific evidence (that I’m sure is already published).
column347: We need to continue research into genetics of coral ecosystems to do our best in finding climate change resistant strains. Many scientists are currently working on this research, and this decade will be important to take the research from concept to active reef restoration around the world. Helping to promote this research will be crucial.
column348: PLASTIC - plastic plastic everywhere. We need to address this and come up with scientific methods to remove plastics from our ocean systems. We are drowning in plastic and it is only going to get worse unless we can synthesize sustainable plastics and clean up what’s already here.
column376: I am a regulatory biologist and have limited ability to speak on behalf of my agency, but would be glad to volunteer as appropriate. Since I’m not in a scientific position I can only assist by volunteering outside of my official capacity.

column421: Early career researchers lack stability in academia. In the UK, it was recently stated that 7% of PhD graduates are successful in obtaining an academic position that allows them to do research. The Decade could highlight the need for ocean research and the paucity of jobs due to limited funding. For instance, I have lived and undertaken a research position in 4 continents and my option for obtaining a research position depends on the success of an Australian DECRA fellowship which currently stands at 15%. While the UN is unable to increase research positions directly, they are able to highlight the plight of reduced funding ok the amount of early career researchers being awarded academic positions.

column420: We need more gender equality to ensure a diverse vision. We need to increase labor security for early career researchers. It is crazy that people are kept temporary in their jobs until they are 40, then they might need to shift to another job so all their knowledge get wasted, they are frustrated and burned out. This especially affects women's lives, as they are often still supposed to be the parent in charge for children care (and anyway are those who take the parental leave, missing months of work that result in weaker CVs in comparison to men).   This is what I see in Europe, people commitment to science is mined by the increasing competitiveness for the few available positions, by the need to look for your next job, and by the need to publish more than other people just to get your scores a bit higher. In my opinion we can achieve something only through collaboration.   The academia must find a way to select valuable people much before in their career (e.g. at the end of PhD), and let the other leave. This way, people who are in can be fully committed to research, while other people can find their alternative ways when are still in their 30s, which would be fairer.

column346: Innovative capacity building approaches based on modern low-carbon virtual communication tools should be facilitate to allow sustainable global knowledge exchange.
column376: I am keen to support the ocean decade with my expertise on knowledge exchange via virtual communication.
column377: As an early career researcher / professional without a permanent position yet,  it is keen to get financial support for any substantial contribution to the Decade e.g. via direct employment, individual consulting contracts or other ways of financial support. Early career professional have to be taken serious and seen as valuable as other partners to ensure they (we) stay engaged.
column420: As an early career researchers I am worried about my future in particular due to dangerous climate change. The next 10 years are crucial and we need action on all levels. I would be glad to see that during the Decade we all will change collectively the way we do science, knowledge exchange and make our practises more sustainable (fly less, walk the talk, ...). If we manage to transform our practise in line with the overall transformation needed towards a more sustainable word our call for action will be strengthened. There are a lot of movements underway in the scientific community e.g. in France www.labos1point5.fr  One concrete example would be to ensure that more funding is allocated for innovative modern virtual communication projects (which are cheap, effective, inclusive etc) and less funding for short fly-in person meetings. Of course in persona meetings are key for partnerships and collaborations and for initial trust building etc But after working on virtual communication projects since more than a year now my colleagues from around the world and I have learned that if a mindset change occurs at all levels (by funding agencies, institutions, personal level,...) a real change is possible. Innovative virtual communication has the potential to make knowledge exchange more sustainable and inclusive. I would be glad to see that during the Decade this topic is given a high priority!
column421: ECOP especially some of my colleagues in West Africa or Peru, who make extraordinary work, often face the situation after their PhD or even several successful PostDoc phases abroad (in the US, Europe etc) that no employment is possible in their home countries. Global leadership fellowships which give long term financial security for these highly qualified individuals, change makers could make a difference in fostering ocean science in these countries. Often their knowledge gathered over a decade of capacity development is simply "lost" as they decide to work in a totally different field to have employment and be able to give security to their young families. Identifying these key individuals who drive ocean science and sustainable development forward in their home countries should be intensified and supported via long term fellowships. A few long term employments might have a more long lasting and sustainable effect than short term efforts for massive capacity building.
